advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl ! Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>found on the system box</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Laser 3000. For 5980F, play the double compatibility !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #3 </strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 - Before the IBM PC became THE universal standard, IBM was looking for good programs using all the features IBM Basic could offer.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Let your imagination take wing.<br> Think charts, Graphs, Shapes, Images.<br> Use originality, creativity and color in programs that entertain, educate, organize, analyse. And programs that get down to business...<br> ...In fact, if you are interested in licensing your software, we could be interested in publishing it...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I clicked"... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY. (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666"> The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br> The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br> At $595 it is astonishing.<br> Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br> Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br> If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIL'Z III</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice fish-eye picture of a Sil'z III illustrating a 1982 article about Technologic Revolution in the french mag TeleSoft.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-502 was also called the Diabolik in France...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">What in the name of Adam do people do with Apple computers?<br> You tell us.<br> In a thousand of words or less.<br> If your story is original and intriguing enough, you can win a one-week trip to Hawaii. Which is the closest we could come to paradise.</font><br><br> Unfortunately, the contest ended March 31, 1980... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-1200 (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The industry said it couldn't be done. You can't put a hard disk in a portable PC, make it powerful and keep it under 11 lbs.<br> Well, with this that challenge in mind, we immediately went to work to prove them wrong, presenting the result, the new T1200... </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD. JUNE 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional adhesive sticker of the RC 700 Piccolo... What a visionary thought!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juan Antonio Maestre for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MITS BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORANGE+ US AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com" target="_blank">www.textfiles.com</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Husky Hunter is a very special computer as it was designed to work in all environments (Aluminum alloy case). It is a rugged field computer.
It has military characteristics : it is waterproof (against accidental immersion) and shock-proof, and its autonomy can exceeds 45 hours (the endurance time of 45 hours is only achieved with Alkaline batteries, with NiCd they only last about 16 hour). The british army was using some Husky-Hunters in 1983. It was also quite used by doctors and scientists in Africa or poor countries, where you need resistant and autonomous computers.
The Husky-Hunter has several programs in ROM: a small NULL modem transfer program and a terminal emulator. It has a also communication-oriented Basic to handle the RS232 and the bar-code reader.
In fact most applications developped for the Husky-Hunter consisted of data entries and then transfer of this data to bigger computers. Hence the RS232 serial port on a standard 25 pin "D" connector. Communications could be done up to a 4800 asynchronous baud rate. There were a wide range of protocols supported, including the IBM 2780 fully synchronous implementation (handshaking: RTS, CTS, DTR, DSR, RI, CD all selectable from BASIC).
The built-in Basic is also very powerful with graphic statements (CIRCLE, LINE, etc.). It is possible to redefine the characters and even the function keys. Another very interesting fact is that there is a real time clock, so that the time of the day is software accessible.
Programs and data can be stored indefinitely in the battery supported memory of the Husky-Hunter. There's even a file manager running under the DEMOS operating system (CP/M compatible).
The Husky-Hunter can also be used to receive data from measurement systems and/or bar-code reader.
The hunter completed his IBM friendly ability with built in EBCDIC translation. The keyboard was completely 'soft' and customizable with poke's from BASIC. The Husky's manual embraces proudly 'full compatibility with CP/M programs for z80 and 8080 procesors.
The Hunter was not the first model. The first Husky, released in 1981, was a bit less powerful, had a LCD screen of only 32 x 4 characters and a flat membrane keyboard like the Sinclair ZX-81.
________
Contributors: Jaume Vega
Steve O'Hara-Smith reports: I once got the opportunity to drop one from the balcony at Earls Court (empty stand below) - it was completely unaffected by the experience and was still running the program it had been running when I dropped it. Try it with a modern laptop or PDA :)
computer.graphics: 240 x 64 dot full graphic liquid crystal display
computer.keyboard: QWERTY rubber keyboard, arrow keys, tiny space bar...58 keys arranged in four rows of 15
computer.name: HUSKY HUNTER
computer.peripherals: Special car case with printer built-in and 12v power supplySuit-case with 12v power supplyWaterproof suitcasePrinter (80 columns)Micro-tapes numeric recorder (2 x 32k, 1200 bauds)3.5'' disk drive
computer.ports: RS 232 (25 pin) - LEMO Port (used for Bar Code) - Tape

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Serial DB25 connector and light-pen mini-din plug </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 80K VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Seems to be a military version with 80 KB RAM and khaki case. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jean-Michel Jauffrit</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 352K VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>352 KB version with white keys and user template allowing the user to write its own function labels.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jean-Michel Jauffrit</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HUNTER 2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Hunter 2 Optimal had same features as other Hunter models apart from a larger LCD display.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jean-Michel Jauffrit </b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> HUNTER 16</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Hunter 16 was launched in 1990.<br> Although it looks like other Hunter models, its internal hardware was radically different. A 16-bit NEC V25 (8088 compatible) CPU took place of the Z80 CPU, and CP/M was replaced by MS-DOS 3.3 + GWbasic.<br> Internal RAM was of 1 to 4 MB. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jean-Michel Jauffrit</b></p></blockquote>

computer.sound: 1 voice, 4 octaves range, programmable frequency & duration
